description:
In this head to head review of the 9070 XT and 5070 Ti I look at performance and features including RT, Path Tracing, FSR 3, FSR 4, DLSS 3, and DLSS 4 at 1440p and 4K Resolutions in a variety of games. I also look at value analysis for both MSRP and real-world pricing.
Buy an RX 9070 XT: https://amzn.to/41NqvPc
Buy an RTX 5070 Ti: https://amzn.to/4kwUdPQ

Test system specs (ResizeBAR/SAM ON):
CPU: Ryzen 9800X3D https://amzn.to/40Nor9v
Cooler: Corsair H150i Elite https://amzn.to/3VaYqeZ
Mobo: ROG Strix X670E-a https://amzn.to/3F9DjEx
RAM: 32GB DDR5 6000 CL30: https://amzn.to/41XRtkM
SSD: Samsung 980 Pro https://amzn.to/3BfkKds
Case: Corsair iCUE 5000T RGB https://amzn.to/3OIaUsn
PSU: Corsair RM1000e (2023) https://amzn.to/3Z1XjS5
Monitor: LG 32GS95UE https://howl.me/cmk7W9HiD2F
Keyboard: Logitech G915 TKL (tactile) https://amzn.to/3U7FzA9
Mouse: Logitech G305 https://amzn.to/3gDyfPh

What equipment do I use to make my videos?

Camera: Sony a6100 https://amzn.to/3wmDtR9
Camera Lens: Sigma 16mm f/1.4 https://amzn.to/36i0t9t
Camera Capture Card: Elgato CamLink 4K  https://amzn.to/3AEAPcH
PC Capture Card: https://amzn.to/3jwBjxF
Mic: My actual mic (AT 3035) is out of production but this is a similar mic (AT 2020) https://amzn.to/3jS6LEB
Portable Mic attached to camera: Rode Video Micro https://amzn.to/3yrT0R4
Audio Interface: Focusrite Scarlett 2i2 3rd Gen: https://amzn.to/3wjhlad
Greenscreen: Emart Collapsable https://amzn.to/3AGjQXx
Lights: Neewar Dimmable USB LED https://amzn.to/3yw4frD
RGB Strip Backlight on desk: https://amzn.to/2ZceAwC

Sponsor my channel monthly by clicking the "Join" button:
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC_ozUuauyPf1CgXztIWTOGA/join

Donate directly to the channel via PayPal:
https://www.paypal.com/donate?hosted_button_id=4G7D2YRVT9EDG

Disclaimer: I may earn money on qualifying purchases through affiliate links above.

fulltitle: RX 9070 XT vs RTX 5070 Ti- The Ultimate Comparison!!! (Early Access while I make timestamps, etc)

comments.text: Basically get a 5070ti
comments.author: @Paulog2003

comments.text: price difference as of May '25 between cheapest 70XT and 70Ti is roughly 100 euros in favor of AMD. I don't mind paying an extra 100 to get nvidia featuresets, widely supported DLSS, actually playable path tracing performance, Ray Reconstruction and lower power draw. But AMD is clearly catching up, the next generation should be very interesting, and we might finally be able to see a real fight between the two, which is great for us, consumers.

comments.text:
If the 9070 XT was actually available at its alleged MSRP in my country, I would've been a bit more tempted by it. Sure: even though the 5070 Ti is currently available below its MSRP, it's still a bit more expensive than the AMD-card. But the difference isn't so big that it would've made me want to switch to Team Red (and go with a slightly less powerful card). The whole reason why I upgraded is that I need more GPU-horsepower (and VRAM) for VR, after all. 
I bought a 5070Ti on the weekend and its lowest (on sale) price was EUR 797 at the time - regular prices go as low as 818, ATM and MSRP is 879. The cheapest 9070 XT was going for 750. All these are consumer prices, BTW so no added taxes or any of that nonsense. The XT has dropped to 720 today, but that's still slightly above the MSRP they communicated around launch-day. Which was/is 689 IIRC.

comments.text: One thing is strange. They had a pretty good value "build it yourself, complete PC bundle" where I live, one with a 9070 XT the other with a 5070 Ti. About 300-400 cheaper than if you bought the parts from other online stores here. I couldn't make up my mind if I should buy the 9070 XT bundle or the 5070 Ti bundle, I kept looking at benchmarks and it seemed like the 5070 Ti on average performed better. Well I waited too long the 9070 XT bundle sold out (it was the better deal). And now when I was "forced" to buy the 5070 Ti bundle every benchmark I look at seem to show the 9070 XT being more powerful. Sucks being so indecisive. The remaining 5070 Ti bundle is still better value than anything else available, (it also sold out, but I managed to order one in time). The 9070 XT bundle was 200 cheaper and obviously the better deal. The 5070 Ti bundle does come with Doom Dark ages however.

comments.text: The only complaint I have with your benchmark videos is that you don't include the live fps graph. So we aren't able to see how the games are spiking comparing each GPU. What I've noticed is that with the 50 series cards they have less fluidity and the FPS deltas between high and lows are higher than on AMD. This translates into more stuttering and less fluid gameplay than on the AMD cards even if those clock at the lower average FPS as long as the deltas are smaller they end up feeling and looking smoother

comments.text: I'm gonna be honest, dlss 3 and 4 give a lot of frames but it is a lot more choppy than fsr. It's something that has always bothered me and I can notice when I turn on dlss. Leads to missing frames and miss matching frames. Where as fsr 3 and 4 may show a lot of artefacting and slower response rates it feels way less choppy than dlss.

comments.text:
There is nothing edge because he was not notices the memory usage  between them which was also need to consider. RTX 5070 TI is a gddr7 and rx 9070xt is GDDr6 which has major performance diff in hardware level.

in all games 5070 TI using 2K MB memory more than 9070xt which shows major diff. if you push rx9070 to the same mem range it will perform even better on theoretical level since it was non controllable in first place. I know FSR is less quality when compared to DLSS but it you max it VMS usage with the range level games which use 16gb Vram then 5070 TI shows it ugly side.

if you ask me 9070 XT is giving most giving equal performance with low cost and low power consumption also. literally you can add 2 9070 XT for that calculaltion boost if SLI there.

comments.text: Percentage is what matters. 30 to 40 is an incredibly noticeable improvement. 100 to 110 is hard to notice without a framerate counter running. So saying "10 fps better" is basically useless without knowing the framerate you started with. Percentage difference accurately shows the difference in those scenarios. 30 to 40 is a 33% improvement. Big, noticeable. 100 to 110 is 10% improvement, which is why it isn't very noticeable.

comments.text:
may I suggest something for your videos Daniel? the average versus 1% lows as a metric. because if average is 60 and 1% lows are 58, that would be silky smooth experience and with metrics you are showing at the moment they compare in average but 1% lows can dip very low from that average on certain cards and in certain games. 
for instance the metrics in 4:58 of this video shows the 9070XT is at 202fps average and has 1% lows at 168fps and that difference is not the same as 5070Ti has more "headroom" between it's average at 226 fps and 1% lows at 181 which is 45fps difference versus 34 on Radeon card, so just as my example the framerate is smoother on 9070XT than on 5070Ti even if upscaler makes the 5070Ti look better in overall score in percentage vs percentage score. yes, the frames are higher but they are also further apart on RTX card.
edit: this is even more noticeable on 6:40 where 9070XT has 11 frames per second difference while 5070Ti has 28. that's a 254% difference in between the average and lows of one card to another.

comments.text:
Great testing but when comparing frame rates the image quality needs to be identical. We currently cannot compare nvidia vs amd cards well because of the different upscaling technologies. We can only compare raster and upscaling technologies seperately. Despite the 9070xt being better value, if a game does not support fsr4, you cant really push fsr 3.1 above ultra quality without it looking bad. Dlss 4 performance for same image quality. When you do that you realise the nvidia card is worth more purely down to dlss 4. If a game supports fsr4 that difference is cut drastically and amd is worth more substantially.

Amd wins market share by making sure all games get fsr4

comments.text:
@wolniacha_tv I have a RX 6800 too. This isn't a knock on you, just pointing out some information that is often overlooked since I'd guess most of us (including me) are more invested in PC gaming and building, so these sorts of things tend to be valued more when compared to what the average gamer, especially those new to PC building, actually values. It is definitely possible to use raytracing on this card if you mess with settings or use FSR, but the pay off isn't there and personally I don't like it much to begin with. If I had a 5090? Sure, I'd use the hell out of raytracing, but not with this card lol.

However, FSR/FLSS looks like absolutely trash no matter who you chose. Even the most recent DLSS has plenty of artificats, smearing, smudges, etc. It's just not worth it when the rasterized performance is already more than capable of having playable fps on these higher-end, or at least newer, GPUs. I can see utility with them being used on lower-tier cards, but the fact that NVIDIA is providing benchmarks using DLSS EXCLUSIVELY is scummy and misrepresentative of the GPUs actual performance in rasterization, which matters significantly more to me, and hopefully most other gamers. I acknowledge it's a setting that is oftentimes automatically enabled by most games, but it's really not worth it in my opinion. I can play most games around 80-110 fps 1440p Ultra as is so I'm not missing anything, and I'm not someone that really cares about super high-framerates since I don't play anything competitive. Only Rocket League, and I play that VERY casually.

You may also consider that Nvidia gets worse performance when the card receives any driver update near the new generation arriving while AMD proceeds in the opposite way, every upgrade of drivers makes better the performance in their cards.

comments.text: Having seen a lot of closeup footage of DLSS3 and 4 vs FSR4 I would say that appart from Ratchet and Clank (which was also particularly egregious with FSR3) I think saying FSR4 "is roughly on par with DLSS3" is wrong. It's clearly between DLSS3.7 and 4. And it even does a few things better than DLSS4 (less tendency to cause disocclusion). And performance wise it's on par with DLSS4 but DLSS3 is a little faster. Which basically boils down to: It's good enough. People were already very happy with DLSS3 (basically it was DLSS2.2.1 that was the point where people stopped complaining about ghosting and shimmering) and found it superior in almost all cases to going a quality preset down. If FSR4 is a notch above that, then it's good. And it's especially good for a first attempt. I suspect AMD will keep pushing ever closer to Nvidia from now on.

comments.text: You don't have to make this complex. In pure raster the 9070XT is slightly faster, in RT the 5070 TI is much faster, like 20-30% faster. Overall the 5070 TI is slightly better due to its DLSS 4 being slightly better and being much better at RT. But it costs at least $200-400 (20-40% more) more on the street so who cares. If you want to play Indiana Jones, Black Myth or other heavy RT games, get the 5070 TI, if you don't care as much about RT, get the 9070 XT. If you don't have a microcenter near you (you're never getting an MSRP card) so just get a 9070 XT when they restock. Same chance of getting a 5080 at launch during each restock which is occurring more frequently than the 50 series. Good luck. You can wait 12 months but tariffs are not likely heading lower and demand will remain high due to supply shortages. It is what it is. Think as if its worse than the 30 series release, because it is. Prices won't stabilize for >1 year and perhaps up to 18 months or so and they will stabilize at a higher level. The new cards will be on a more expensive node so expect higher prices then for that reason as well. Save up some $$$ or give up PC gaming as a hobby / get a switch 2. Those are your choices.

Don't forget to factor for the potential missing ROPs. It might be a rare occurance, but you have as much chance as anybody else of getting a defective card.
Considering the 5070ti wins by "on average 8%", and the missing ROPs seem to average at 10-11% loss of performance (if you get one of those cards), that would lead to paying more for a worse card.

Granted, people in the know will likely send them back and have to wait for a replacement unit, which they then play the lottery with again. But there are a LOT of people who either won't know to check, or will accept the card because they don't want the aggro or the wait involved with replacing it.

An overlooked problem with all this is how much "nonexistent MSRP" has broken the used & last gen card market.

The cheapest 4070 Super I found on Amazon was $956. Used ones are selling for $700+ on Ebay. Hell, I found a new 4060 Ti 16GB sell for $816 on Ebay as well.

Now if you go back to the 30xx series & don't mind lower VRAM, you can find some sub $500 cards, but they're still selling for more than they should be at this point.

comments.text:
In the last 2 generations of GPUs there is an obvious issue no reviewer is addressing. Do we need or want to pay an extra grand for a few visuals? RT is not a gamer friendly gimmick. The cleaner faces, shades and shadows do not add to game play. The cycle is wicked and way out of balance. It is condemning consumers and the only people truly benefiting are tech companies and it is short benefits as parts will be so unaffordable, we will just go back to console gaming.

 Devs are trying to keep up with what tech companies (Nvidia by strong arm tactics) force them to do and GPUs come out with such a small upswing, that there is no generational value anymore. In 2017 we were not clammering for tiny upgrades and hoping to pay 900 for a GP when our 300 GPUs would last 5+ years. 

 The last 2 generations of AMD and Nvidia GPUs make no sense at all. It is all hype and no value. Every tactic being used on launch is strictly to getting addictive personalities to feel like they are going to miss out. They over pay for already overpriced GPUs to go back home and play a game that still works great on 3 generation old GPUs.

 Every reviewer is using top spec gear to do reviews and using generic benches. So how does this benefit us?

comments.text:
@24:00 about RT 'reviews'. In my opinion, the best way to provide us with the most relevant data is to include only 'playable' results.
What I mean with that:
Card A does 10 fps in 4k path tracing, Card B does 15. We can put this on a graph and say that card b is 50% better. And it would be accurate. But for me, that's useless, since its just 5 fps more. If card A does 100 fps and card B does 150, then, that's a 50% better card that really makes a difference.
Now, how does one define 'playable'? Is it 30 fps? is it 60fps? That's a different question :D
But I personally dislike percentages differences because the % number when we are comparing low numbers is big and can be misleading on the real world usage of the card.

comments.text:
There is also issue of customs and taxes, which is rarely thought about when people talk about MSRP. 
MSRP of 600$ in US can become 800$ in other. It isn't some global selling price recomendation. MSRP is often made for USA specifically (and guess what, USA shops do not include tax in price, hence, for example, leaked China price was higher. Due to 13% tax). 

Taking in account additional cost of transit, intermediaries and other similar stuff, it is not that unreasonable to see 900$+ price. Sometimes even 1000+$

There is also such thing as price fixing, to make stock last longer... But in case of these GPU's nowadays it does not really help unless it is really agregious pricing.

In my country there is small stock of new GPU's coming (political reasons).
So 9070XT costed on launch... Around 1300 USD.
Day later they were dropped to 1200 USD.
And via sidechannel methods you can get one at around 900-1150 USD (depends on AIB model and intermediary)

5070 Ti costs around 1500-1600 USD. 

Now is this price difference makes 9070 XT still worth buying even though it is still overpriced? Imo, yes.

But there is big note. 4070 Ti Super costs around same 1100-1200 USD mark as 9070 XT (and seems to he pretty available to buy). This is only potential competition to 9070XT that is realistically available here. But then perfromance difference still is a thing.

4080 Super costs same as 5070 Ti. (But unlike 4070 Ti it seems to be relatively unobtainum. Only model available for largest seller)

So sometimes choice is not as simple as A or B. And what is correct for one country, may not be good option for another.

comments.text: Yea, those scammers list the GPUs with really long delivery windows so Ebay releases the funds and they can run before even shipping anything. Don't buy anything expensive and electronic from China, it's probably a scam. The minimum price for a scalped 5070 TI is ~$1200. And for the 9070 XT it's at least $800 for the MSRP cards if the scalper is looking for a really quick sell or $900 if not. Ebay charges 15% for fees then there's $15-$25 in shipping, so they need to charge an up charge of at least 20-25% to make anything. They typically charge 30% for AMD (since there's more availability keeping prices down) and about 50-100% for Nvidia.

But going from Ultra to High looks better and gives a similar performance boost. At 1440p it's a different story. That's where DLSS was really a problem for AMD because DLSS was perfectly usable, but FSR3 was not. At 4k it's a nobrainer. FSR3 Quality looks OK and DLSS3 looks great, but FSR4 and DLSS4 look fantastic. A 9070XT on a 1080p monitor is going to last him until well into the 2030s. comments.author: @andersjjensen
@JleonardoCard

comments.text: @ Exactly. Most game engines scale linear with pixel count, sans UE5 which speeds up more than you'd expect when you decrease resolution. So a 7600XT/2080Super is as fast at 1080p as a 5090 is at 4k. A 9070X is 2.2x faster than a 7600XT but 1440p is only 1.7x the number of pixels of 1080p... which means that a 9070XT is significantly faster at 1440p than a 5090 is at 4k. Running one at 1080p with upscaling is "CPU bottleneck with extra steps" in almost all instances.

To be fair. Bandwidth is as good as processing unit which uses it.

comments.author: @DimkaTsv

comments.text: Gddr6 at 256bit bus is 6 percent lower than gddr7 128bit. So no. Gddr7 is just marketing
comments.author: @johnpantag472

comments.text:
@ 256 bit bus allows for 2x memory capacity and 2x memory bandwidth. You probably wanted to compare it with 192 bit bus GDDR7.

By your 6% difference on 128 bit bus GDDR7 should've been almost twice as fast to make them even within 6% difference. And 2x bandwidth leap between GDDR6 and GDDR7 could not be called "just marketing"

Except! It isn't 2x, but 40% instead. (Frankly speaking you could just calculated it as 28/20 Gbit/s difference between GDDR6 and GDDR7)

And to calculate how wrong you were:
256 bit GDDR6 (20 Gbit/s) is around 640 GB/s 
128 bit GDDR7 (28 Gbit/s) is around 450 GB/s 

[450/640 = 70% of bandwidth]
192 bit GDDR7 is around 672 GB/s 
[672/640 = 105% of bandwith... At cost of being limited to 12 GB of VRAM (i doubt 6 GB is possible with GDDR7, but 24 GB should not be impossible)]


256 bit GDDR7 is around 900 GB/s
[900/640 = 140% of bandwidth. Checks out]

Anyways...
GDDR7 generational gain is not small. Especially as it is pretty new. Remember, GDDR6 original speed was something around 14 Gbit/s, now it is 20 Gbit/s (and even slightly more for some dies). 

Question of price is important though, and i have no idea on prices.

comments.text: It has a lot to do with the fact Multi-GPU rendering support was not widely implemented in games and other applications as it was yet another thing to optimize for (hence the micro-stutters in games that do support SLI/X-Fire) and by the time Nvidia's NVLink (allowed VRAM to be added together to create a larger VRAM pool) capabilities were released, it was far too late as at that point game and software devs completely dropped support for any kind of multi-GPU rendering setup aside from MAYBE a few workstation applications and even then, it's only the professional GPUs for current gen hardware that would still have support for that.  You'd have to go back to the 30 series (and I think only the 3080 Ti to 3090 Ti) from Nvidia to still find SLI/NVLink support on the consumer side.

comments.text:
@mieczysawmietki4053 I do agree, but when this border is laid, is for consumer to decide.

Prices are not static, neither universal. MSRP is only valid for USA, especially so as US shops do not include taxes into listed price.

But let's go for example.

Would you prefer 9070XT for 900-1200 USD, or 4070 Ti for approximately similar price (depending on how you buy it. Largest store price tag ranges are 1100 -1200 USD for 9070XT and 1100-1400 USD for 4070 Ti. Even aftermarket 4070 Ti are mostly like 100-150 USD cheaper than new ones bought from side channels)?

Or would you prefer 9070XT for 900-1200 USD or 5070 Ti for 1350-1600 USD?  
(There is also 4080 Super option for same price as 5070 Ti, but unlike 5070 Ti it is basically unobtanium as only single model is even available. 5070 Ti is available at quite wide variety though)

Sometimes, 100$ can become large enough difference between can afford and too much. 
And for some countries or some people even 50$ can be enough. So for them such decision is tough.

There are also valid case for opposite as well. Sometimes Nvidia proprietary stack is so important, that people are ready to overpay or buy less performant GPU, just to have access to software stack.

There is also matter of main use case. I, for example, mainly play games that are raster only. 
But i do still want BASIC level of RT for modern titles for which cannot do even basic lighting without restoring to RT, so it must at least work fine (and at this level of RT RDNA4 seems to be pretty competitive). I don't think of actually playing games with pathtracing enabled outside of enabling it from curiosity because FPS mostly becomes atrocious even on Nvidia cards. In other cases.
comments.author: @DimkaTsv

comments.text:
@mieczysawmietki4053  it is efficient overall, unless you hit title with weirdly uncharacteristic performance drop (which is possible)

9070XT is definitely pushed, and with adjustments it can really be efficient without consuming as much power. I am think that lowering it down to 220W should be pretty much possible.

comments.author: @mieczysawmietki4053

comments.text:
@mieczysawmietki4053 UV allows it to be more efficient at same clocks.
Or reach higher clocks at same power.
Basically UV gives more performance. 
UV is modern OC.

But! There is also underclock. Efficiency and performance curve is not linear.
Cutting 500 mHz from clocks would often not result in 500/3000 = 16.6% performance reduction, but noticeably less. (Maybe few percents in this case... Like around 5 from top of my head?
Meanwhile power consumption will reduced by significant amount, aka more than by said 16%

So by UV + UC you can reduce power consumption by... Let's say 30%, and lose around 5-7% performance.

That is how efficiency can be gained.

Yeah, card is cool. I ordered it myself, even though it ended up being bit more expensive than it was originally priced (i wasn't in time, and it jumped 100 USD up that day). But... It does have several desires upgrades from RDNA3 (i have 7800XT right now). And, while i do appreciate NVENC (due to variety of color precision modes) and CUDA (because it works everywhere with AI. ROCm is more limited in support) A LOT, i could not still force myself to buy 4070 Ti at similar pricing. Especially as 9070XT seems to have improved ML targeted operation performance by up to 4 times (may not be 4 times in practice, but it is serious gain. Like really impactful potentially).

I guess Nvidia scored bit too many strikes for my taste recently. I did check 4070 Ti pricing after i made my order, and i had tiny bit of regret due to "oh wait i forgot to check this one" feeling. But even though i had ability to pull back, i did not.

I did not actually stuck to Nvidia ecosystem when i still had their GPU's, as my Nvidia GPU's were 1060 3GB (scummy one) and 2060 12GB (actually not a bad one except it was damn Palit... Never again! These fans were too loud for my taste and cooler allowed quite small margin with power limit increase). Meanwhile my next Gigabyte AORUS 6750XT had  quietest fans i ever had on GPU.

comments.text: The core temperature of the RX9070XT can be easily cooled in any model. But the hotspot and memory temperature are high. When fully loaded, the memory temperature will be around 90C, whether it is high-end or entry-level. As time passes, the hot spot temperature should also increase. For your XTX I would recommend using the PTM7950. And it would be even better if you lowered the voltage a bit.

That's usually why I pay extra for a gpu with a beefier cooler, im not sure if hotspot temps are naturally higher but I usually try to undervolt my gpu to lower it as much as possible for more performance and longevity.

comments.author: @ziggs123

comments.text:
For what it's worth, my 6800xt nitro+ did that too (105'c hotspot). When I took it apart to investigate, the thermal paste Sapphire had used had 'pumped out' leaving part of the die with poor coverage. Cleaned the paste off and replaced it with a graphite pad, and the card has been fine since. Hotspots now are within 5'c of the average and down in the 60-70 range in most games.
Might be worth checking.
comments.author: @winterscrescendo

comments.author: @chrisgonzalez2957

comments.text: In RX9070XT, sapphire and PowerColor use PTM7950. ASUS uses a similar phase-change thermal sheet, though it has not been disclosed. GIGABYTE has used a composite metal grease that mixes metal into the grease to increase durability, and has also replaced the regular thermal pads with a thermally conductive gel to also increase durability. The PTM7950 won't lower the temperature significantly, but it will be much more durable. The thermal pad should fall apart from oil bleed before this stops working. For those who want to reduce maintenance, I recommend Sapphire, PowerColor, ASUS, and GIGABYTE. XFX is also not publicly known, but it is quite likely that they are using the PTM7950.
Undervolt then. Takes 10 minutes max and your card will be under much less stress and you save money on your energy bill.

comments.text: The issue right now is the AI bubble - why would Nvidia dedicate their wafer allocation from TSMC to $600 graphics cards meant for gamers, when they could dedicate it to $40,000 H100's meant for AI startups backed by bottomless venture capital? It sucks, but at the end of the day, both Nvidia and AMD are publicly traded companies, and that puts a fiduciary duty on them to go after what makes the most profit for shareholders, even if it comes at our expense. The best we can hope for is that this bubble pops in the near future, and TSMC wafers can stop getting sucked up to make useless chat bots that can't even solve 2+2 consistently; once that happens, that's when we'll start to see the GPU market recover.

I mean, around two and a half decades ago when I was buying a Matrox G400 in Sweden, the MSRP was lower than even the pre-VAT price I got while my friends in the U.S. could buy one at MSRP. Europe rarely got the benefit of the MSRP and then theres often VAT on top of that.

On the other hand, in the U.S. for anyone that lived close to a Micro Center, the MSRP was very real with an estimated over 3,000 people buying a 9070 series card at MSRP at the 28 stores in that chain alone. The bottleneck is TSMC but they are very reluctant to expand capacities into other countries due to the silicon shield. @Vantrakter Well yesterday there was ONE ASUS 5070 Ti Prime for msrp in Finland which is 930 roughly, this one was 923. It was a shop called proshop that had it, a Danish company I believe but they have a store page for Finland. The way they do the sales is they announce when the next shipment is being sold and then they disappear in one millisecond. You might see the "BUY" button on the store page if you're lucky but when you click it it says that page doesn't exist and the card(s) are all gone.
 If a 5070 Ti ends up being 923 when it's msrp in the US (in theory) is $750 that means a $600 9070 XT should cost 744. If they bothered to convert dollars to euros then it should cost 0.92 * 600 * 1.255 (Finnish VAT) = 693. But that never happens. I don't know if there is a single 9070XT for sale anywhere however, the cheapest one proshop has listed is 870 (but they don't have it or any 9070XT cards in stock). comments.text:
@hartsickdisciple i think supply being somewhat limited isn't necessarily a new thing... I used to work at RadioShack in the late 90s early 00s. On Black Friday and certain launch days of cell phones or certain new Compaq PCs, we would sell out by lunch time and have people coming in constantly for days trying to get one.  Also, this happened for years at nearly every console launch and iphone launch, and even some Samsung galaxy launches, but i think the NEW thing is the price jumping up astronomically once the units sell out.  if you line up at the apple store and are unable to get the new iphone, you wait one week, you go back, you pay the same amount as you would have on launch day, no worries.   Same with PS5, same with xbox or really any other thing out there.   But not with GPUs in the last 2-4 years...  I mean in what world is it okay that if i don't click the button fast enough to purchase a $600 product, it has suddenly now become a $900 product?!   OR worse... my $750 hopeful purchase is now a $1399 purchase?  OR WORSE  my $1999 purchase is now a $5795 purchase?!
That is NOT okay, it SEEMS illegal, and i'm almost positive there is some kind of law or trade rule or something being broken...

and people telling me to just wait and get one... well, i have no choice now, but... i waited on the B580, and 3 months later it is STILL like 40% OVER msrp BEFORE tariffs kicked in, and unavailable even at that price half the time.   and we all know nvidia cards are hard to get, admittedly the 5070 is somewhat in-stock right now, but, no one wants that next to the 9070 / XT....    so, it could be months before the AMD cards are back in-stock.... likely after they release the 9060s.

interestingly, neither nvidia or apple are certified with the BBB, but the BBB has kept a profile on both regardless, and nvidia has an F rating with the BBB.   Apple has an A+ rating.
